did.abstract: This collection consists of two letters written by Isaac S. Catlin, a District Attorney in Kings County: one is to John A. Dix, Governor-elect of the State of New York, 1872, and the other to General Franklin Townsend, Adjutant General of New York State, 1879.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Xerxes Fine and Rare Books and Documents, 1986.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The two letters are housed in one folder in chronological order.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Major General Isaac Smartwood Catlin was a District Attorney in Kings County. According to Lain's 1880 Brooklyn city and business directory, he practiced law at 201 Montague Street and lived at 189 Bedford Avenue. He was a civil war veteran and active in political and legal circles in Brooklyn. He had a daughter, Charlotte Catlin Graves, and a son, Captain George Catlin. He died on January 20, 1916 in his apartments at the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn Heights.

list.head: Source:
list.item: "Major Gen.Catlin Dies of Apoplexy." Brooklyn Daily Eagle, January 20, 1916, p. 10.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Isaac S. Catlin letters, 1986.003, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was rehoused and the finding aid revised by Dee Bowers in 2024. At that time, the collection was renamed to reflect the correct name of the letters' author, who was originally identified as "J. Cather."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of two letters written by Isaac S. Catlin: a letter to John A. Dix, Governor-elect of the State of New York, recommending Colonel David E. Austin for the post of Commissary General of Ordinance, dated 1872; and a letter to General Franklin Townsend, Adjutant General of New York State, recommending a General Jourdan for a vacant Major Generalship, dated 1879.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: These items are in the public domain.
